This is a nice spot to check out the Blue Angels during Fleet Week. You can see a good crowd of people camping out at the top of the hill as well as people hanging around on the east side steps. A lot of folks also hang out at the east base of the hill along the road, to catch the aerial show.

If you are a workout junkie, GVP provides at least 3 different set of stairs for you to run up and down. Also, the 16th avenue steps is further down on the west side as well as another set of stairs on the north side takes you down to 16th and Kirkham.

You can also jog or walk around the streets that circles around the hill. So much to do for one grand hill!!
author: Sam T.

description: Beautiful views of the city from the bay all the way to downtown. You can see the Golden Gate Bridge up in the distance too. The two paths up to the top both meet at the lookout point. The views from each level of the stairs are not bad either!
author: Jing L.

description:
The panoramic view from the top is definitely wonderful, especially when there is no fog (something that's definitely a factor here in the west side).

Hiking opportunities are pretty limited though, it seems such walks are limited to the two stairways leading up and down and the sandy trail just beneath the peak.  The stairway leading up from the south side (Noriega Street) is wooden but less steep and therefore probably an easier climb than the concrete steps on the north side.  In fact, one can see these wooden steps leading to the top from the area around Noriega and 19th Ave, it's such an interesting sight in my mind.
author: H K.

description: Beautiful view of the city. You get a full view of everything the city offers at this park. The stairs to get to the top are tall, but worth the climb. I suggest having someone take your picture here if you are on vacation-you will love the background!
author: Stephanie H.

description: SF is abundant with beautiful parks and this one is my absolute favorite for both the view and experience. Do not forget your camera! Starting up the Moraga and Hidden Garden steps and then up the stairway of the park itself, it's a continuous photoshoot all the way--and since you'll be stopping at every corner for photo ops, you won't even feel like you're trekking up all these stairs. The view from the circling pathway at the top is most definitely a GRAND view. Don't miss this if you're visiting the city. It's rated 5 stars overall for a reason!
author: Emi N.

description: Without a doubt one of the best views of SF. You can see the GG bridge in the distance, GG park (very a la Central Park from above) and the Pacific Ocean all in one swoop. Prepare to walk up some stairs, but absolutely worth every single step.
author: Mel G.

description:
This park really does have a grand view of the city. It's a lot smaller than say twin peaks, but it's also a lot less crowded which is a plus in my books! So depending on where you park or start your walk up, the climb up the Moraga steps takes about 5-7 minutes. It's a nice little exercise up to the top.

The view up there is great. There is only one bench, so there's no actual seating available up top, but the view will take your mind off of that. Best view of the sunset neighborhood that I've seen thus far.

It's a nice neighborhood treasure to have. Beautiful sunset/sunrise views as well!
author: Junel S.

description:
Such an amazing place! If I can give it 100 stars I would. 

You are first greeted with beautiful mosaic steps that brings you to the very top of the hill. I'm not from the area, and was brought here by a friend's cousin. It's fairly hidden and unknown. Also from what I heard, not many tourists come here.

However, it has one of the most beautiful 360-view of San Francisco I've ever seen. Just have a look at the pictures. The view was simply breathtaking.

Highly recommended to anyone and everyone who visits San Francisco.
author: Michael L.

description: Good exercise to get to the top, but the view is great. I won't say breathtaking, but uh yeah it is. A stunning panorama of the sunset district and beyond. There are some benches, and rocks, could be nice for a lunch.
author: E. W.

description:
After walking up the 16th Ave Steps (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-16th-avenue-tiled-steps-project-san-francisco#hrid:x0DGBD8wbg79eMhvlsRdGw), we kept walking and what do you know...we stumbled up Turtle Hill (aka Grand View Park).  The hill is incredibly teeny but climbing the stairs to get to the top can be a challenge for some.  Great views of Sunset, downtown, and if you look hard enough, the GGB.  But like I said...teeny once you reach the top.  Not one of the those places you would want to chill and enjoy the view with a lunch or anything.  Just climb, snap pics, and walk back down.

Great views but not one for the hiking books for me.
author: Ninja H.

description: AMAZING view of the city!!! It's such a hidden gem that I never knew about this spot. It's quite a ways getting up to the park after going up the mosaic stairs but it is absolutely beautiful. It's also freezing and windy once you get to the top but the view is breath taking.
author: Jeena L.

description: great little secret place in SF. on a clear day you can get a great panoramic view of SF from downtown to the ocean with the Golden Gate in the middle.  It's also a quiet place. So hike up here and just take a look at a view of SF that post cards and internet searches missed.
author: Jason C.

description: Although Ironically one of the most IG'd (Instagramed) and facebooked locations in the large metropolitcan city of San Francisco, it is actually located in a fairly quiet neighborhood. The view truly is grand, as there are very little visual obstructions such as trees and buildings that may deter you from taking a great panoramic of the city. Be forewarned though, as the popularity of this place slowly rises, so do the amount of visitors, which makes all the more challenge for a tourist-free picture of the breathetaking staircase. Best of luck, definitely come in the daylight if you'd like to see the stair case.
author: Hansel B.

description:
LOVE this park. It's one of my top local secret spots in San Francisco. I've been here both in the daylight and late at night, and both are just amazing. There's a single bench at the top facing Golden Gate Park, but you don't even need the bench to enjoy the sights. From there, you can see Sunset, Richmond, Downtown, and the entire span of Golden Gate Park. Simply beautiful.

This is my favorite local spot to watch the fireworks on New Years Day too. There aren't very many people, AND the view of the fireworks in addition to the view of the city is a spectacular view.

I also tend to meet the most unique individuals up there too. Once I met a man who gave my friend and me a quiz on San Francisco, because he wanted to make sure we were "true San Franciscans". He asked us how many miles San Francisco was in length and width. He said 7 miles by 7 miles, but he was also drunk, so I'm not sure if his answer was correct...

The only minor problem I have is that I get lost about 90% of the time trying to find it, and then when I finally do find it, there's the trek of climbing a million stairs to get there, but I suppose that's what makes it so amazing :)
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Best view all the way from ocean beach to GG park to the top of GG bridge to DT SF to the east bay to the top of twin peaks. 

A hidden gem!
author: Chesca A.

description: You get a great view, almost 360 of SF up here. Golden gate bridge, downtown, golden gate park, etc. Site can be quite romantic with the moonlight guiding your way up. Beauty day and night!
author: Henry P.

description:
I love how you can see both downtown and the ocean while standing in the same spot.

Its quiet, not crowded.

Only drawback is the broken glass all around the top of the hill.

Came up here on a beautiful Sunday afternoon after walking up the Moraga steps (Moraga St between 16th and 15th avenues) to the base of the park.
Note that you'll have to walk up a lot of steps to get to the peak of the park to savor the great view.
author: Norman P.

description:
I really didn't know much about this park until I was walking in Golden Gate Park and noticed a hill topped with trees to the south. I looked on the map to see what it was and how to get there and next weeend I came up to Grand View Park. 

The park earns its 5 stars just from the amazing view at the top! There are a lot of stairs but the climb to the top is definitely worth it. There really isn't much more to the park than stairs and a view but that doesn't make it any less sensational. One can spend a couple of hours a the top just examining the view.
author: JD R.

description: So my dear friend Samir and I were waiting for our Tour de San Francisco partner Kiersten to arrive to walk over to Golden Gate Park.  We were parked near Enjoy Vegetarian Chinese Restaurant in anticipation of working up a huge appetite for the evening repast.  I wanted to show Samir a great walking area, but Samir was already better informed and experienced than I was.  Up 12th to Lawton we went.  Past that to Moraga.  Then westward up Moraga to 14th Avenue and several sets of really steep steps.  Check out the pictures I took.  What a great day Friday, April 6th was.  What an incredible vista!  So this is Grand View Park.  How lucky the Inner Sunset residents are to have this park so close at hand!
author: Em S.

description: This is one of the best views of the city by far. 360 and sitting just high enough above everything, the city feels tiny and huge at the same time. It's a little bit of a work out coming from either stairway, but it's very manageable if you pace yourself. One side comes up from the tiled steps, and I recommend doing a joint trip for the two. Beware of the raised metal steps though. There is railing but for those uncomfortable with small heights, it can feel a little lacking in support and scary. The alternative is a stairwell on the other side which hugs the hillside, so that's less intimidating.
author: Grace T.

description:
When I really want to get away from it all,  I head to Grand View Park at the top of Golden Gate Heights and right smack in the middle separating Outer and Inner Sunset Districts. 

I spent the most beautiful morning on the steps of Golden Gate Heights again, and up to Grand View Park for the most spectacular views of the entire City.  

Once at the top, you have the Pacific Ocean to your left, Golden Gate Bridge in front of you, and the Downtown skyline on your right.   And right there all alone, I couldn't help but think to myself  "It really doesn't get any better than this!"

I've been so busy lately, so it was such a great treat to be spend my Sunday morning enjoying the weather and the beautiful views by myself reflecting on important things in life.  

Grand View Park beats out Twin Peaks for me because of the fact that it's right in my neighborhood, and there is rarely anyone around...so tourists are really missing out on a treat (A good thing, as the last thing this place needs are the flocks of  footsteps from tourists) 

I love the little benches that are scattered around for those picturesque quiet moments to relax.  

After enjoying the views of Grand View Park, I continued on my trek for more Golden Gate Heights steps that seem to just pop up out of no where---Cascade Walk, Aerial Steps, and Mandalay Steps, and of course my favorite 16th Ave and Moraga Tiled Steps.   It's so much fun wondering where you will end up next.  

Hands down, my favorite spot to get away from it all, amidst the beautiful views where I can enjoy my own time all to myself!
author: Cass J.

description:
I went here for the first time today and WOW! What an amazing view!

You can see absolutely everything - downtown, top of the bridge, the bay, the park..

What a great place to hike up to and spend some time sitting on a bench :)
author: Deirdre L.

description: great outing along with the stairs, love this place. Great for tourists.
author: redtulip s.

description: Fantastic panoramic views of the city. It's the place to capture photos of the fog rolling into the city (though I didn't see the Golden Gate from here...perhaps I was too late). The only hitch is that you'll have to climb a flight of stairs to get to the top. The best way to stop here is to park just below the mosaic steps (16th street tile steps) -- free parking and head your way up!
author: Mimi C.

description: Beautiful spot and more peaceful to me than Twin Peaks. You have to walk up a lot of stairs in order to get to the view point so you do not see too many drunk people with their music blasting late at night. I definitely recommend this spot, which is possibly the best view in the city.
author: Joey I.

description: I love urban parks. The view at Grandview is nothing less than spectacular; it's vast and romantic. As obsessive as I am with Google Maps, it was awe-inspiring to see the streets lined in real life: foggy Golden Gate Bridge, Richmond district, Golden Gate Park (with de Young museum, California Academy of Sciences, 19th avenue/highway 1), Sunset district, Forest Hill, UCSF/Mount Sutro, Twin Peaks, Point Reyes, downtown SF, and much more. So beautiful.
author: Jay C.

description: Nice vista point to enjoy the view of the city. It is a hill with a great set of steps, like spaghetti strewn across the hillside. If Twin Peaks is pretty for the overwhelming view, height, and area then Grand View Park is beautiful for its enchanting charm of being a small, captivating, and intimate vista. If the trip up Twin Peaks is great for making one anxious and excited to reach the end point then the trip up the stairs of Grand View is great for the making one enjoy every step and every detail. Twin Peaks is about being at a great view. Grand View is much more about the journey traveled and arriving to a great view. A much more intimate place you share a moment with between the people you arrived with.
author: Kelvin M.

description: A lovely little park, just one more reason to love this city. The view is great, but the emphasis is more on the Sunset/Pacific Ocean than a full 360, IMO. The steps up aren't bad, but it will likely be quite windy at the top. We tried to have a picnic once with limited success. Lots of off-leash dogs.
author: Megan S.

description: Great view of San Francisco. You can see the Golden Gate Bridge. Took me a while to get there by bus, but it was definitely worth the trouble. Walking up the stairs to the top was tiring, but it was worth it when I got to the top and saw the beautiful view. On the other side, there are Moraga steps which were very beautiful. This is a place worth visiting.
author: Sylvia H.

description:
Climb up the exquisite 16th Avenue Tiled Steps, a wooden staircase, another staircase, then take in the view: Pacific Ocean, Marin headlands, the Golden Gate Bridge, downtown, homes, churches, etc. Make sure to go when it's clear. 

(Completely personal aside: I went to vibrant, sunny, hot Utah last week and grey, foggy, cold San Francisco has been a bit of a Debbie Downer. This view made not being in Utah anymore suck less.)

Enjoy.
author: Yan E.

description: This IS the best view in SF. Not as busy as all the other places like Twin Peaks and you get a full 360 degree view of the entire Bay Area which includes the Golden Gate and Bay Bridge. It's not that hard to find this place and this is the perfect place to just chill out and relax after a long stressful day. Amazing!
author: Stephen D.

description:
It was one of our earlier dates. One clear, brisk Sunday evening, after a long day of work he called me up and asked if I wanted to get something to eat and hang out with him for a bit. Of course I said yes - he whisked me away to Gordo Taqueria to get some burritos, then drove to houses unfamiliar to me in the Sunset. 

"What are we doing here?" I asked. 

"You'll see." He replied. 

He took out a blanket from the back seat of his car and with burritos in hand I followed him to the bottom of a staircase. Looking incredulously at the height of the stairs he smiled and urged me to start climbing. On the steps were murals of the journey, starting from the ground to the sky. 

I remembered being tired and restless but I kept following him up. It was already dark and as he gingerly took his steps on the dirt, he grabbed my hand and led me to a bench with one of the most beautiful views of the city that I've ever seen. The bright red and yellow lights of the western part of SF, the black silhouette of Golden Gate Park dividing the Richmond and Sunset Districts, and the always breathtaking Golden Gate Bridge was our backdrop.  We sat down on the bench, covered ourselves in the blanket, and started talking and eating the night away. 

"This is my favorite place in the city." He began. 

"Do you take a lot of people up here?" I asked. 

"No," he said, "You're one of the only ones." 

I love this place and I love this man.
author: Devy E.

description:
This is place is great for workout. If you are someone who don't believe paying gym membership, come to this place, you'll get some cardio workout. Don't forget to get your dumbbells. 
There's plenty of free parking everywhere, so no worry
author: Spike P.

description: Despite the fact that this park is just 4 blocks away from my cousin's house and I'm always there playing with my niece and nephew, I've only been up here twice. It's kinda a steep walk for the kids and though it seems to take ages (guess that's what happens when you have to constantly stop and smell the flowers, grass, bushes, etc) it's worth it because you can see all the way to the ocean at the top - not one but both windmills in the park! And the De Young! The Golden Gate Bridge! Downtown! Seems to be a popular spot because they've got benches up there as well as broken glass and prayer flags (try explaining prayer flags to kids). People kept appearing and leaving during the time we were there. You'll never get this spot to yourself.
author: Jean K.

description: This is a great place to exercise and an amazing view. With any body new that I meet I always show them this view. So relaxing and a romantic view for couples. Definetly suggest anyone to walk up there but car works too lol
author: Rosa A. F.

description:
If you have never been to "turtle hill" the SF natives like to call it then you have not seen an amazing view of Golden Gate Park, the Golden Gate Bridge and the ocean....on a sunny day!!! It's also very pretty on a clear night as well but you need to be careful!!!

Not only do you get to see three beautiful parts of the city but you also get an awesome workout for your bottom and legs, lots and lots of stairs to climb!!!

Bring some water, wear some good shoes, bring your camera and take in the amazing view of part of SF!!!
author: T C.

description: SUCH a great view.  At the top of the 16th Avenue tiled steps, there are more steps leading up to the top of hill where after a climb, you will be treated to a breathtaking view of the city.  It's a free attraction, and is definitely worth visiting.  Whether you're a local or a visitor to the city, this place is definitely a must-see.
author: Christine W.

description:
AKA Turtle Hill ..Some days I like to climb the stairs and view my beautiful city. This used to be a stoner hangout not that I know anything about that. 

Thanks to the diligence and pride of neighborhood residents the staircase was replaced and benches were installed.  The ecology is being protected now. Monterey cypress trees to the Franciscan Wall flower and Dune pansy.

This is a small park less than 2 acres. On a clear day one can view the Golden Gate bridge, Pacific Ocean, Golden Gate park and the San Francisco Downtown skyline as well as other hills like Sutro tower in a 360 degree panoramic view. 

The park is a 140 million year old geological Franciscan rock formation formed from sentiment, dust and sand blown and carried via rivers from the California Sierras. 

I love coming here to relax and gain perspective on life. I am really glad there is a bench overlooking the grand view. I love that workout climbing up the stairs. Check it out if you can.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
My math isn't that great, but let's give this a shot.

Twin Peaks - Euro trash - fobby tourists - hormonal teenagers at night - sorority girls posing in their letters - families - any type of crowd + a flight of gorgeous, mosaic tile covered stairs = Grand View Park.

GVP at 14th and Moraga is where the Sunset's best kept secret can be found, high atop a few sets of relatively easy to climb stairs. Not strenuous at all, just perfect for a peaceful, 360 view of one of the most beautiful cities in the world.

Go.
author: Betty W.

description: Awesome 360 view of San Francisco . It was a beautiful. The stairs was kind of high got me tired half way. But i am scared of height and out of shape. Older people we're passing me up lol . A must see if ever visiting sf.
author: Nguyen L.

description:
After my walk up the The Tiled Steps Project, I found more steps leading up... and up. I can't help but follow steps when I don't know where they lead, and when I see others also climbing upwards.

Once you make it to the top, you're in for a gorgeous (albeit chilly) view of San Francisco from all sides. You can also watch foggy clouds roll in from the coastline. 

Climb for the view, take lots of pictures, but if you're thinking of hanging out for a bit, don't forget a jacket! It was a 27 some degree day in SF (Celsius, I believe that's around 80 or so Fahrenheit) and I was getting goose bumps just hanging out up there.
author: Wendy P.

description: If you're ever in the Sunset District when visiting San Francisco, this is the park that you must visit if you want to reach the top and see spectacular 360-degree views of the west side along with Golden Gate Park and yes, Ocean Beach. Which means climbing a large number of steps, but you know what? It's worth the exercise! Try to come on a sunny day if you want to see the most beautiful views, although I'm sure it'll look just as nice on a foggy day!
author: Paul N.

description: I would have to say I absolutely love the view from here! It offers a 360° view of frisko! Definitely worth making time to check it out if you're in the city. Such a romantic view :)
author: Jenny S.

description:
I can't believe I never discovered this place in my 25 years of living until recently! 

I knew about the tiled-steps on 16th, but I didn't know there was this amazing space beyond those steps! It's like a tiny hut with a spectacular 360-view of the whole city. I like how there's a bench for people to just enjoy and relax the mind. Air is also very fresh. You are so high up that the ocean waves look like an oil painting.

Those steps don't look like much, but they will definitely work your glutes. I think I just found a new favorite place to relax! :)
author: Jenny M.

description:
This place has one of the best views of the city! The only major issue I have with this place is the weather at the location. It is almost always foggy and damp when you get up to the peak, where a "grand view" is (supposedly) spread out before your eyes. But during the warm, sunny days, you can see as far as the Pacific Ocean. At night, you can see the breathtaking city lights gleaming from the buildings and homes of the S.F. citizens. While you're up on the peak, why not snap a few photos too?

Also, if you're one of those people who like to get out of the house for a workout, you should make a visit to Grand View! :)
author: Winnie W.

description: A great 360 degree view of San Francisco. I've been here at least twice in the past 6 months; the city is continually improving it and helping to preserve the area. There's some native foliage that grows only here in the city, only place it's left actually, since there is some of the original soil from the sand dunes that were leveled to make Golden Gate Park, housing, etc.
author: Ken L.

description:
Twin Peaks jr. 

Crowded at times with runners, tourists, lovers, and anyone else with enough impetus to climb up how many steps?!! 

Amazing panoramic views. 

Really worth it. Expect wind.
author: Mr S.

description:
Like many other yelpers, I had never been to this park until recently. Getting there can be a bit confusing if you're driving, but parking is plentiful, and the view is definitely worth the climb up those steps. It's not crowded like Twin Peaks, but don't be surprised to find a group of teenagers hanging out there, with some, ahem....questionable substances. 

Best time to go would be late-afternoon, but if you're going to go at night, remember to bring a flashlight. There are tree roots sticking out and the dirt path is not level in some places, plus there are no streetlights. But all that can be forgiven, because the view is phenomenal.
author: Nadia A.

description: Fabulous hidden treasure! The tiled Moraga steps are beautiful enough, but climb them and another couple hundred to the top. The summit of Grand View Park is tiny, but offers spectacular views completely across the SF peninsula. Often bathed in fog,  but get there on a clear day and wow!
author: Richard D.

description:
San Francisco, thank you. You're views are amazing and your hills from which i look out from are outstanding.

Grand View Park is pretty much just that... one of the grandest views of SF. Lets see... you get the ENTIRE Sunset and Beach view, the Golden Gate and Richmond areas, of course there's parts of Downtown... i mean really, you can almost see it all.

But gosh, you're telling me now i have to climb back down?!
author: Greg G.

description:
I've been meaning to visit this park for a while, but I never made the trek until this afternoon. Simply amazing views of the Pacific, top of the Golden Gate Bridge, Sunset District, GG Park, and downtown all from a perch atop a big hill with lots of beautiful trees.

Getting here by foot is a bit of a workout--the most direct (but maybe not the easiest) route from Golden Gate Park is to take 15th Ave up to Kirkham and taking the scary, secret stairs up between 14th and 15th Aves up to Lawton St. From there, you can take another set of stairs at 14th and Moraga or 15th and Noriega up to the very top. (You could also drive, but it wouldn't be as rewarding... :)

Make sure to save a good spot on the west side of the hill for a perfect view of the sunset. I noticed a lot of couples came up here for a smoochfest (blah) but you also get a lot of joggers and random folk, too. One of SF's best-kept secrets, in my opinion...
author: Richie K.

description: Went there yesterday by myself. There were a lot of people-- usually couples, group of friends and ppl exercising; few tourists. I watched the sunset and it was beautiful. I want everyone to see this place.. but at the same time, somehow, I wanna keep it a secret.
author: Yer L.

description: OMG this place is very amazing.  Good hike going up and the view is amazing.  I didnt even realize this place exists and we only happen upon it by accident.  All I can say is "wow"!
author: Elc C.

description: Amazing. Can't believe I used to take friends visiting to Twin Peaks.
author: Jordan R.

description: One of the best views in San Francisco, 360 degree, sand dune park.
author: Ernst L.

description: Tourists all head to Twin Peaks. Grand View Park is so much better: more likely to be clear, much less crowded, panoramic views. There are quite a few steps up, and it's not the easiest to find even with GPS. But whenever I have out of town guests, we head here. I almost didn't write this review, because I don't want it to be spoiled. Probably half the time I go there, I'm the only person on the peak.
author: Frank W.

description: I have never actually been here before despite living so close to SF and always going to the city to sight see. There is a very beautiful staircase called the Moraga Stairs that leads you up a hill. For those with heart conditions you should probably take it easy. The staircase is made from colored tiles that create images and they look really nice. Very unique little something. Once you get up the stairs you can keep going up and up more flights of stairs which are plain, no color or pictures. But once you get to the top there is a bench and a pretty amazing view. I came during sunset and it was goregous. Good little vista point to walk to.
author: Jeromy G.

description: Perfect for little workout and great place to sit and absorb the beauty! Gorgeous sunsets from here!
author: Juliana B.

description: I come here on any day with friends and park the car along the streets and just chill in the car. Chitchatting while looking at the awesome view of this beautiful city. It's not overrated as twin peaks and it's super close to sunset district. I love it!
author: Lydia C.

description: I was curious about this place boasting so many amazing reviews about the cityscape, I was even more excited that its not too popular (#instanthipstercred). I went there last weekend and it was BEAUTIFUL. It's an unsuspecting park with amazing views of all of SF, you can see from one corner of the city to the other all in a quick walk through the sand/dirt pathway. This is not just for tourists, its definitely a place for anyone wanting to see the hotness that is SF. PS- parking along the street is super easy.
author: Rina M.

description:
Another place with great views to the city!

There are only a few great stopping points with sweeping views that won't be scattered people here and there.

Great views of the northern portion of San Francisco.

TIP: Pretty dusty paths (not packed/paved trails), so wear close toed shoes
author: Angel L.

description:
I cannot believe my sister has lived four blocks down the hill from this park for the better part of a decade, and I just finally climbed the stairs to the top this weekend.  In my defense, I live twenty-two hundred miles away, but you would think that would mean I'd be itching to get to the highest vista possible when I come out!  From this point on, Grandview shall be my go-to get-away whenever I'm in this beautiful city, since I can see so much of said city from the top.
The view east is breathtaking, as the city winds behind Mt Sutro, the view north is a beautiful vista of the Golden Gate Bridge behind the park and the Presidio, but my favorite, the view west, is the shining city gleaming white in the sun as it stretches to the ocean and the vastness beyond.  I wish I could have stayed for the afternoon with a picnic and a bottle of wine to watch the sunset.
author: Kevin M.

description: From here, I would ponder... deeply ponder... windswept and fogged in, a little drunk and lonely and underemployed and with time so vast and pocketed with decay spread out like gridded avenues across the landscape of my self-importance. Back when I lived in the Inner Sunset, this would be my go-to, and if I still lived here, it might be. I'd take 14th straight up until you hit steps, and goddamn there were a lot of them, and damn if they weren't steep. But for a lonesome time in your lonesome life when you just want to be alone, looking out at the vast enormity of Life's Miracle happening in front of you, do climb, and ponder... do ponder... bring a coat.
author: Roy M.

description:
It's 5 o'clock somewhere and you've got a hot date. Out the door of your building you gaze up to find a clear sky. Should be a beautiful night tonight.

A quick trip to the Sunset brings you to the bottom of a steep wooden staircase. You smile, happy to have remembered to wear your sturdy running shoes. One strong step at a time you climb, spiraling around a dusty hillside. Each set of stairs leads to another and you cant help but stop to admire the view in between. At last your trek brings you to the top of the hill, your eyes wide with delight as you take in the view. 

360* of Beauty .

You take a moment to find a comfy spot, finding every viewpoint to be a fantastic one. With not a tourist in sight, you settle in to enjoy a serene San Francisco sunset. The sun slowly sets, colorful lights highlight your view. From the top of the hill, all your worries seem so far away, you are at peace. 

The sky grows dark, time to go. Slowly hiking down the stairs, you watch as the city's lights begin to illuminate the night. You head home, satisfied and smiling, already longing for another hot date.
author: Caroline J.

description:
Great work out to get there.

Over 5 endangered species to ogle.

One of the best views in the City.

When there is not 80 days of straight fog, best sunset view as well.

Good for a date walk and talk.

Try a picnic, a picnic with wine that is.
author: Joe Bob J.

description: This little park - which basically amounts to a bench on top of a hill - is pretty wonderful.  If you are lucky enough to visit on a sunny, warm day it is a real treat.  Or you can go on a less pleasant day and watch the fog roll in which is kind of interesting but I mean it's really cold and windy, so just be prepared for that ok?  Either way the view is as good as you're going to get in this part of town and the tile stairs are really lovely.  Oh yeah, it's a lot of stairs to get to the top.  Totally doable but just be prepared.  I like to walk up on my lunch break to really feel like I'm doing something "active."
author: Shauna L.

description:
This used to be the place I'd go to when I needed a little bit of fresh air to clear my head.  It was right in my backyard and offered a challenging walk up to a beautiful view of the slower side of SF and Ocean Beach.

There are a few ways to get up to this little park and my favorite is the mosaic steps at 14th and Moraga.  You can see the sun, moon and stars embedded in the steep steps leading up to the wooden stairs that take you to the park, which offers a bit of whimsy as you huff and puff up.

Each time I've gone it's been windy, so a jacket or sweatshirt will definitely come in handy.  It's not a great place to picnic though due to the rocky outcroppings and uneven ground, but great if you just want to sit for a little while and take in the sunset.
author: Janet L.

description:
Grand View Park is perfect if you're looking for a panorama of San Francisco.

Up many thigh-busting flights of stairs and a semi-steep hill of loose sand and dirt, over a few makeshift-ladder rungs of old tree roots sits a small bench that, when sat on, can make you feel like you're at the top of this city. 

The view is magnificent.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: After you surpass the crazy amount of steps, you are able to see the beauty of the whole city. Great place to take a friend, a date, or someone who is visiting SF.
author: Sonlay V.

description: This park offers great views of the city, but the hike is rather short and the park itself is rather small.  The worst part is the weather at the top of the park can be windy, cold, and foggy.  Otherwise it's a great place to bring guests for a one time city view treat.
author: Victor S.

description: Sadly, i visited this park when it was pretty foggy. But it was still a breath-taking view. Deff. worth the many beautiful stairs we have to walk to get up to the top. Read the words of the bench, btw.
author: Analleli G.

description:
Home of the prettiest staircase in SF; the Funston and Moraga mosaic stairs feature bits of glass and ceramic fish, flowers, bats, squirrels, and birds.  Families and business names are imprinted on some of the pieces (e.g., Arizmendi Bakery).  Flowers have been planted next to the stairs.  Towards the top, the tiles and glass form a mosaic picture of a moon and then a sun above that.  

Once you climb to the top, veer to the right a bit and go up the concrete steps to reach the wooden steps that take you up to the top of Grand View Park.  The park is small and peaceful with sandy patches and trees. It gets very windy up there and you can see (not surprisingly) a grand view.  They have problems with people leaving broken glass up there so wear shoes.  If you climb down the other side, you'll find another set of concrete stairs.  

Caution, the Moraga tiled stairs can be slippery.  They're also fairly popular but not as popular as the Lyon Street Steps.
author: Lolia S.

description: Lovely view and improvements are being made on walking paths and maintenance.
author: Gregarious B.

description:
As the last sizable hill before the ocean, this park is a must for vista-lovers.  It's also got a *very* recognizable profile, basically a tiny clump of trees atop a very round looking hilltop, leading to its nickname of Turtle Hill.

On a clear day you can see the entire sunset and richmond districts, the Golden Gate Bridge, and even downtown SF, though the view to the southeast is blocked.  Great place to take SF newbies on a geographical-orientation tour of the city.
author: Wes M.

description:
So that's the name of this place, huh?
The wife and I have spent many a sunset here....
....just us, fresh air, a blanket, couple of glasses, and a bottle 'a vino.
Sprinkle in some good conversation, the occasional passing of
a wagging canine, a smiling face or two from other passers-by, and the feeling is right up there with that post 160 bpm artery-cleansing endorphin high, minus the sweat.
Well I did sweat there once....
...and cried...
...and got one dirty knee...
One crisp, clear Christmas morning...
...its where I got engaged!
author: Barry A.

description:
Finally climbed to the top after living in San Francisco for 2 years.  Not as convenient to get to as Buena Vista or Corona Heights, but is a great 360 degree view of city, GG Park, Sunset, and Ocean Beach.
Definitely worth the climb!

Not protected on a windy day, so try climbing the hill when the wind is calm.
author: Keith K.

description:
How many names?

Turtle Hill
Golden Gate Heights Park (incorrectly)
That hill in the inner sunset
14th and Noriega....
That mural stairway park

Whatever it is, I have seen more PERFECT sunsets, and more serene, maddenenly beautiful moments of my lifetime.  6pm.  11pm.  2:30am.  4am.  7am....

so many moments, thoughts, people.... so many of the most dire moments in my life... those imbued with energy and emotion, and love, and expression.

I love that damn place.  Little windy at times, tho.

I am so glad I live a block away!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
We made the trek up here today...have you ever noticed that the hardest part of most "hikes" in San Francisco is getting through the residential area to get to your hiking place?

The view is amazing, and the benches are perfectly placed (great quote on one facing Ocean Beach: "The violets in the mountains have broken through the rocks")- though I am a little sad they are all dedicated to dead people who died young. Debbie Downer!

There were a bunch of kids playing capture the flag, which was really charming considering they were about the age when they really should have been smoking pot in their parents' basement.
author: S F.

description:
The view (like the climb) is indeed quite spectacular and even more enjoyable if attempted on a clear warm day in November with barely any wind.

360-degrees of gorgeous -see the entire city - from the edge of the ocean beach and the acres of the Sunset, to the Presidio and far into the Castro... we are blessed to have these places in our fair city.

Bring a book or the paper and some refreshment for a beautiful, quiet, absolutely stunning afternoon.  

It's not much of a place to take the puppy (the climb is good, but there's not much space to run around).  Also - beware the broken glass scattered about that could hurt tender paws...
author: Claudine C.

description:
Wow, nice moves you got there. Grand view is right.

Oh, didn't you know that everyone on Mt. Sutro can see you?
author: GIR ..

description: great views of the city. Hands down better than twins peaks, no tourist. There 2 ways to enter grand view, (Funston Ave & Moraga St) or (15 Ave&Moraga). But if you come from Moraga & 16th Ave you come across never before seen tiled stairs.
author: Robin L.

description:
i would like to have my future home around this area. The view here is great. I love how it's still in SF, but secluded.

I came here on a beautiful late afternoon and love it. I like the houses, the roads and the VIEW.

Watch out neighborhood, DLee wants to be your next door neighbor.

The stairs is cool. I like how there are benches for people to sit and enjoy the sunset.
author: David L.

description: Really cool mosaic on the stairs leading up to this place from 16th avenue. Looks like a steep climb, but it's not bad. Great view of the city from the top. Word of advice. Don't go on a foggy day like I did.
author: Linda H.

description:
I always take out -of-towners here. I love that it has amazing views and no tourists. (Unlike Twin Peaks, Coit Tower...)

I feel I really am a little hard on tourists, considering 6 months ago I was one. Saying that, I didn't wave my disposable camera in people's faces, clog the streets waiting for a cable car, and hold up buses cause I had no fucking clue where I was going. So I take it all back. 

In fact, I take everything back: Don't go here...it's terrible. Especially you kids with your Smirnoff Ice. ...Wow! I'm just hating on everyone today.
author: Ali L.

description:
When it comes to being romantic and making my heart skip a beat, my one and only never fails to amaze me.  So he looks up (on yelp, of course) this place since we love nice views (and everything that comes with seeing one).  Not many people know about this place (versus Coit Tower, and btw do NOT go there!  Those added bushes covers the view and it's just played out, so at least go to Twin Peaks instead).

It's easy to find parking here (I've always wondered what it's like to live in the houses nearby these scenic spots).  Make that lil' hike up the stairs, you'll be wheezing and gasping for air like me (jk, I'm not too bad with that I think) and when you make it to the top, lo and behold, you'll see all of SF, no matter where you turn.  This is the time to get an all around 360 degree view of the city, which I like.  And plus, it's never crowded here, the max # of people I've seen here is a few (and for some reason, they're always with a dog, but I like dogs so it's all good).  You can enjoy a nice, quiet moment with whoever you're with/by yourself.  I'd go run up here and read a book, shoot.

So, make the trip here.  Actually before you do, go hang out in Golden Gate Park, since it's nearby.  And after you do, well, Twin Peaks is only a couple miles away.  Might as well take in all the lovely sights of SF in a given day.
author: Lili K.

description:
Here you stand watch over a tranquil view superimposed upon a rock of fearsome wind shear.  The ocean looms cold and omni in a flat, unmoving line.  Adults are bunkering in their homes before you in all directions trying to keep warm; their kids alongside you are puffing up with rather similar goals.  I suspect some are from St Francis Wood, others maybe from Miraloma.  

This is the penultimate birdseye of the San Francisco Outlands, beautiful and yawning before you ... the only place where  you can stretch your arms and hold all of Golden Gate Park at one time ...  the only place where the Sunset monotony is revealed to be a beautiful swan, and for possibly once a day where those smart green flashes can be seen as our only Star burbles and sighs 'neath the ocean blue.

This place is the most magical part of the City that you've never been to.  Make it a habit at least once.
author: Jim W.

description: I came here on a foggy day, so it was so surreal seeing myself up high and just seeing fog in front and below me.  It's almost spooky with the trees.  It's a small walk up to the top, where there's a bench perfect for pictures.  There's also sand everywhere.  I would definitely try to go on a sunny day because I hear it's a great view.
author: Lily N.

description: Okay, here's what you do. You go to Underdog at 17th and Irving, and get a delicious veggie hot dog and tater tots to go.  Then, you go to 17th and Moraga and look in awe at the beautiful tilework on the stairs leading up to Grand View Park.  Climb, climb, climb, eat eat eat. so pretty!
author: Mark S.

description:
Not what I thought it would be but ended up being more.  It's not a "park" per say, akin to Lafeyette.  It is, however, the most beautiful overlook I've seen to date.  The sights:  downtown, old Golden, the Pacific, Twin Peaks.  Once you overcome the steps, there is a sand path that circles around to the overlook at the top.  

FYI:  Some jagoffs (Pittsburghese for a-hole) must think it funny to break bottles up there so watch where you step.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I want to get married here. And to me, it's Turtle Hill.

I have friends who grew up in the Inner Sunset who took me here a year ago, but most importantly it's where my smoosh A grew up. The view is so amazing, you get to see a little bit from all different angles. Very panoramic. There this zen like calm at sunset, and euphoria I feel when I'm there, regardless of my day.

When I use to visit from the East, and A lived up in Sac at the time, it was our tradition on our last night before I fly home to grab some coffee - climb those damn stairs - and sit for a while. He told me before, it's where he goes to think, hangout, fall in love, and apparently almost burn down the hill (but that's his story to tell). I can agree with him about the falling in love. Everytime I had to leave, I fell in love with him more on top of that hill, and just knew I would be back for good.

A year later, a district over in the Richmond, but I'm in SF and we're working on getting back to the Sunset. Still, it's one of my favorite places in this city to fall in love, it's what makes SF home to me.
author: Jacquelyne L.

description:
Please don't tell anyone about this park. I want to live across the street from it one day. Or if I'm too poor for that (likely), I'll just live in a tent within the boundaries of the park. 

Sunday was a warm day in the city, & the usually everpresent cold wind that makes this park barely tolerable wasn't blowing. Consequently, it was the best place to be in the city on a warm, late Sunday afternoon.
author: Pete J.

description:
Please if you go here at night, BRING A JACKET!!! I had a thin jacket on and probably caught a cold, but it might have been worth it! The view is nice but I only wished that I had come here during sunset or sunrise instead of at night.

I find the view here comparable to the one at Twin Peaks, but I think Twin Peaks has the edge. When you're at twin peaks you can see this as a small mound . What can you expect though, its in the middle of sunset so that's about as good of a view as you can get there. I've driven around this area hundreds of times before but never noticed this park until Yelp. It's a nice find and pretty cool to have it situated where it is.

An interesting note - I read a sign while at Grand View that said it was a mound of living organisms covered by dirt. That if I looked closely you can see this. It was night so I couldnt see but I'll come back next time to check it out!
author: Colin H.

description:
A friend of mine told me about this park and decided to take me up there one day. One could take the 66 here and start the great climb up the absolutely beautiful mosaic staircase. Not even halfway up the staircase you can already get a wonderful view of the Sunset and the Pacific Ocean, especially around sunset. Once having made your way up the mosaic staircase and perhaps a hundred more steps, the sight is UNBELIEVABLY gorgeous. You can see the Golden Gate Bridge, the Marin Headlands a bit, the city, nearly everything.

It can be a terribly romantic place or just a nice place to sit and ponder about life. I recommend this place to any one who's willing to climb up 200 steps at most to set their eyes on the most wondrous sight of San Francisco.
author: Lauren L.

description: If you've seen the zig-zap steps of this place while cruising on 19th Ave, you may have thought - I need to check that place out!   Well if you have a clear day to explore the Sunset, I highly recommend it!  It's a true treasure of San Francisco. You'll feel a sense of accomplishment after an energetic climb to the top. Enjoy the breathtaking views and know that you've been to a place that many San Franciscans have never even been to!
author: Dan S.

description: Great view of the sunset and richmond districts that the view at twin peaks misses. (review of twin peaks here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/twin-peaks-san-francisco#hrid:PNUGo1HLFy0FCG7lIssbww) It gets cold and windy so be prepared. The "park" is really small and there is only 1 bench. The day my good friend and I went to visit, we saw a trial of "love letters" and felt we were intruding on someones love trial. Anyways good view and good place to bring out of towners
author: Robert Y.

description:
Wow. What a gem in the middle of suburban Inner Sunset. It is so incredibly random but I think that it is totally awesome and amazing and all the above. 

My friend found out abt this place. It's so romantic and beautiful at night. The sky was so clear and I could see so many stars and constellations (Orion's Belt yo) and the view of the city was even better. It is definitely worth going out of the way to look at. I would like to see what the place looks like in the day time.
author: Dustin H.

description: Went up on a clear day and the view was amazing! Totally worth the stairs :)
author: M M.

description:
Today was absolutely beautiful and two of my friends and I took 40s and fruit tarts up here and had a picnic. There really are 23095824 stairs, but it's worth it, really. 

This is on my list of top 5 favorite places, ever. Don't wear sandals, because it's kind of steep, and there is sand and dirt and yeah, kind of a lot of glass at one point, but at the top there is a little bit of grassy area, as well as some neat rocks and a bench looking out over the city. It's really small, but feels very private. Love it.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Quite possibly my favorite view of San Francisco. Though Twin Peaks gives you that majestic (almost) 360-degree aerial view of the city, Grand View gives you a most unique perspective...you don't feel as "on top of the world," like you do at Twin Peaks, which is kind of a good thing. At Grand View, you still feel like you're IN the City, like you're in a really tall tree, looking out.

Not as easily accessed as Twin Peaks, but the mosaic staircase on 16th Ave is quite pretty, and there is the plus side of not having to deal with gobs of Eurotrash and HK tourists
author: Sachi T.

description:
Awesome views of the ocean.  This is my favorite place to relax and think.  The winds are almost always really strong here though, so it is not quite the romantic picnic spot you may be searching for.

On a clear day you can see the Farallons here as well.
author: Rob K.

description:
I've lived in the sunset almost three years now and never had the guts to climb those stairs above 19th Ave.  However, I felt a challenge come on within the last month, perhaps part of my New Year's Resolutions (that and good weather).  Last Monday I was off and it was one of those rare, gorgeously warm weather days in February, so the hubby and I took a walk/run up the thousands of steps or whatever to get there.  I was huffing and puffing around the halfway point while he was already waiting at the top.  

We hiked from below 19th ave, through the mosaic tiled steps, then up another set, and finally to the park itself.  A lady at the bottom of the staircase asked if we were going to the top and we said yes.  So she asked us to say a prayer for her cat buried up there.  We said okay, and then carefully walked through the sand (kind of wondering exactly where she buried the kitty).

Since it was a clear day, the view was just absolutely breathtaking.  I think it was the first place I've seen in SF where you can really see everything, probably even more that Sutro if I can remember.  You can see the entire line of treetops from Golden Gate Park, the Golden Gate Bridge, Angel Island, North Bay - Sausalito area, downtown, the ocean as far as the Sloat side to where it crosses the Bay on the other end.  It was just so amazing and so tranquil.    

Once you're up there, you'll totally forget about the thousands of steps you have to walk down.
author: Stacey C.

description: Best Kept Secret Park! This has some amazing views of the sunset and GG Park. Seriously romantic except for the occasional gale-force winds, and you gotta work the gigantic staircase to get the payoff view. 2 staircases - one off 15th one off Moraga. We had a fantastic burning torch dance one night, and we did pack our trash. On a day were the sun is setting on the pacific and you swear you can see hawaii on the horizon, this little hilltop is unbeatable.
author: dave p.

description:
This park helped me to learn that I am becoming more of a local than I thought!  The girlfriend and I went for a leisurely walk in Sunset Heights on a sunny Sunday morning.  From the top of Grand View Park I could point out most of the local attractions and a fair number of the neighborhoods - all this after living here for about a year!  I'm so proud of myself :)
Plus we say a red-tail hawk flying around (and getting badgered by some ravens... evil evil ravens!).  It's a little oasis in the Sunset.
author: Suzanne G.

description: It seems like a lot of people I've talked to don't know about this little gem of a park. You can see from Parkside and Sunset to the Cliff House, The Presidio, Richmond District, and Golden Gate Park all the way down the Panhandle. It's pretty much a 360 view of the best city in the world. You can not see downtown.
author: Chris I.

description:
I couldn't believe there was a place like this in the Sunset.  I've been living here for a year and drive by it every week on 19th.  The view is gorgeous...I felt like I was at one of the highest spots in the city. 

After viewing the colorful porcelain stairs while passing Moraga, I decided to just park my car at the base of it one day to walk up it.    It took like 5-10 minutes... at first I assumed that you had to walk up a steep dirt trail to get to the top, but eventually I realized there were stairs.

I also didn't realize the mound I was walking up was actually called a "park".  Anyways, I'm surprised that there were just 5 people there with me on a Sunday afternoon, for a view that amazing.  Gotta return for a sunset.
author: M K.

description: I'm not going to pretend the view here matches the view from Twin Peaks. It doesn't. But it is so much more rewarding. The climb up the steps is a decent workout, and the view at the peak is breathtaking. Very peaceful and relaxing. There were less than 10 other people, and maybe 2 or 3 dogs, but it really feels like you have the whole lookout to yourself.
author: Kevin B.

description: Super awesome place to check out! It looks like a ton of stairs, but really it's not that bad. Plus on a nice day, you can get a beautfiul view of the city. =)
author: Maple C.

description:
Looking for a view of the Sunset, Richmond, Financial District, and the beach?  Look no further than Grand View Park.  The view is expansive and the breeze is cool at the crest of the hill.  Coming to this hill is like seeing the rest of what you can't see behind Twin Peaks.  

It's a bit of a maze to get there, but it's well worth the journey...
author: Qyon G.

description:
i feel this place is one of the cities best kept secrets. the view is absolutely beautiful and a great place to bring friends from out of town. interestingly enough, ive never been to this place in the daylight. so i really cant talk about the types of people that frequent the place or if its crowded or not. but at 2 in the morning on a clear city night its always great to go there with either "someone special" or a group of friends and gaze at the endless city lights that surround you. 

only problem ive ever faced with this place is that it took me about 4-5 times to figure out that by going left when you reach the top of the stairs brings you to a little trail that takes you directly to the top. i always immediately went right and had to climb the steep ridge to get the to the benches with the views. typical me. oh, and believe me when i say this, if its windy in the flatlands, it will be twice if not three times more windy at the top of this hill. so choose your day to go wisely.
author: Andrew D.

description: this place is so beautiful.  everytime i drove down 19th ave i always looked up at this spot and wondered how to climb those stairs at the side. my roommate and i climbed up the other side of it though. i thought it'd be slightly bigger but i found it to be rather small. but it's alright i guess. the spectacular view of the city makes up for it. you can literally see an 360 degree view of everything, minus the trees in the way. it's the perfect get-a-way spot, what with the random bench posted there for you to sit on &take in the sights of the city.
author: reiko o.

description:
definetly visit if you're wandering through SF. 

it's got unbeatable views of the city and the surrounding cities. plus, finding this place is an adventure in itself.  i came when it was super foggy out and it was eerie not being able to see off the point. 

the neighborhood is pretty sweet. would love to have a place out here.
author: Joanie K.

description:
We saw the most beautiful mosaic steps one day along Moraga in the inner Sunset.  We were curious where the steps would lead and decided to climb it.  We kept following the steps and it took us to the most fabulous view of SF!  Almost 360 degrees!  Downtown to Golden Gate Bridge to Ocean Beach to Daly City.  

The best part was, there was no one there!  Just us!  This is by far the BEST place to watch the sunset in the city!  Just gorgeous!
author: Ruby F.

description: One of the best hills to have a wide view of the city. This is a good place to view the sunset too.
author: David B.

description: If only it wasn't foggy so often it would get the full five stars. This is one of the best views in the city and no 'tourons' to spoil the view (i.e. Twin Peaks). Like others say it is quite a workout to get up there but we often use it as a personal stair master. With the views of the city and the ocean it's always rewarding while doing reps to the top, or just a great place to watch a sunset. I wish people wouldn't break their beer bottles up there as it gets mixed in with the sand and sticks in your shoes or dogs paws. All in all the most relaxing and spectacular viewing spot in the city. And if you come up from the west there is an amazing mural-ed stairway coming up from 16th ave.
author: Nate S.

description: Even if you are insane and don't like parks with amazing views there is no denying that the mosaic staircase leading up to this park is one of the coolest beautification projects you will ever see!
author: Drue C.

description: As a staunch west San Francisco advocate, I love this park.  In particular, I love that comparatively few people know about it, which means that I can surprise friends, dates, and visitors with a great new view of the City they haven't seen before.  While the park itself isn't much to look at, the view merits five stars.
author: B L.

description: Beautiful panoramic views and great memories. I had a first date here in another lifetime with a lovely Irish lass named Dierdre. If you ever read this Dierdre I can still feel the sensuous softness of your lips. Thanks for showing me this jewel of a Park. Sidenote for the haters. If you can't review from the heart dont fucking review at all.
author: Brad B.

description: When the hubby is looking bored I make him take me walking around the city in search of cool new places to find. Part of the fun of being newbies here is exploring - something people never seem to do after living here awhile. The photos of this park say it all. You climb up on top of the world at this park to some of the most amazing views in San Francisco. Gorgeous, and right above the beautiful 16th St. mosaic staircase.
author: margot b.

description: Best view of the park and most of SF. I've been to all the top views...Grandview to me tops them.
author: LS L.

description: I love this place! It is not very well-known; a friend introduced me to this place back in 2001 and I just call it the "other best view of SF" It is a hidden gem and I always take friends here.
author: Caitanya M.

description: Gorgeous views 1 block from my place. Not to mention an excellent workout running up and down the steps!
author: J H.

description: This park really showcases why the Sunset District is the place to live in the city (if you prefer a house w/yard - love the outdoors/nature and peaceful/quiet atmosphere w/access to everything else in the city). Grand View Park in addition to everything else....the beach, the fresh gorgeous weather (thanks global warming!), the views, the Park Chalet, Sutro Hts, Lands End, easy train access (L or N) to the heart of the madness (which of course I love) of the city....Stern Grove, GG Park, Fort Funston...all and more at a 360 degree view really reminds me why I love to live here. Please only share this secret little gem of a park with those who respect and appreciate the natural side of the city.
author: Amy E.

description: This is a local treasure. You get a bit of exercise climbing the stairs up and then you are given a wonderful 360 degree view of NW SF. You shouldn't have any fear of mobs of tourists like at twin peaks and parking is easy. Like at most of the vistas around the city it can get windy.
author: Andrew M.

description: Great peaceful place with nice view
author: Chong L.

description:
I am new to the area and I am busy researching places to go and things to do on yelp all of the time.  I ran across this park in just that way and I was really excited after reading all of these super nice reviews.
I took my boyfriend for a nice romantic surprise just as the sun was setting.  I struggled a bit with finding the place but that could just be because I'm new to the area and I don't quite have the hang of the crazy san fran streets yet.  One thing that all the reviews seemed to agree on is the fact that it is secluded and a good place to be alone.  This was not the case on the night that we went.  We went on a Saturday night and there was around 10 people there with the same idea.  10 people doesn't sound like a lot but it was a bit aggravating because it's not the biggest place.  Also, one of the reviews described the place to have a lot of benches and places to sit but really, there wasn't anywhere for us to sit.  We had to walk back down a little ways and stand to watch the sunset.
Overall, this was a beautiful place and I got major points for taking my boyfriend here.  The sunset was amazing and it is a charming spot to be by yourself or take a loved one.  Definitely take a jacket and enjoy!
author: Amanda M.

description: After traveling on 19th Ave for all of my 23 years of life, I have never thought of venturing up the hill towards the little hump with trees on top till a couple of days ago.  With a break in the rains and an overcast setting, we climbed up the stairs and circled the small mountain...cameras in hand.  The place has such a nice view.  You can basically see the entire Golden Gate Park, Academy of Sciences, DeYoung Museum, Financial District, and the coastline.  Not many tourists go up there which could be a good thing.  Lots of people walking their dogs but that is fine since I love dogs anyway.  Its a good place for a quick photo op of most of SF.
author: Tiffany V.

description: One of the few things in life that will deliver exactly what it says.  It's called Grand View, and you will find very grand views there.  Walking up, you'll get a lot of exercise and feel like you've had a bit of an adventure.  If I didn't live near Grand View, I don't think I'd ever even know about it.  So it's pretty quiet up there.  And oh yeah, great views.
author: Lego S.

description: A little gem that i was very lucky to find in a little grey Sunset Disctrict that i live in. Wonderful views, quiet, romantic and those steps are worth finding... :-)
author: Katja S.

description:
the most beautiful view in all of san francisco. peaceful, windy, serene, breathtaking...a must-see. 

to quote the bench on the top of the hill..."be thyself: unique and beautiful."
author: sarah i.

description: My favorite view spot in the city.  Always peaceful (no tour buses a la Twin Peaks) and offers a panoramic view of the Golden Gate Bridge, the Headlands, and the west side of the City.
author: Dave R.

description:
i lived next to this park for four years, and the view is indeed amazing, although personally i think the view from the top of twin peaks is a little nicer.  easiest way to get there: starting at funston & lincoln, take funston ALL the way up the hill until you reach a wall.  there's nowhere to go but right at the wall (noriega ave.), so just take that right.  when you get to the stop sign at the end of the block, the park (and the hundred or so stairs to reach the top of it) will be right in front of you.  

please stay on the path in the tiny park, btw.  some rare, endangered plants grow on the hillside there; they can't take being trampled.  and for the love of god, take your bottles back down the hill with you.  the broken glass really detracts from this little gem.

also, this place should be voted "best place for underage drinking after dark," based purely on the number of high school kids i saw (and HEARD) getting hammered up there.  saw a few get busted, too.
author: Jeff W.

description:
like every view in San Francisco.

its better on a sunny day or to see the sunset over the city.

if it ain't. it ain't worth the 'excerise' it takes to get to the top of the hill.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description: Reading reviews of how beautiful the view is or even looking at pictures of it will not compare to what you will see once you get up there. One of the most beautiful views of the city, especially during sunset. The stairs look mean, but they're not too bad. I went here right after the beach, so I had on flip flops, which is not the best idea since there is a lot of broken glass on the ground. Wear shoes, bring a sweater and maybe a camera and be prepared to be blown away!
author: kat a.

description: Without a doubt my favorite view and place for just admiring our fair City from what feels like a birds-eye view.  Great for solitary exercise and also romance!
author: Dwayne A.

description: Possibly the best overall view of the City. It certainly rivals the view from Twin Peaks, Bernal Heights, and Mt. Davidson. Sunsets from here on a clear day are amazing. Be prepared to hike up some major stairs to get to the top.
author: Tim K.

description: The best view .. the most beautiful sunset.. peaceful, never too many people...
author: Fabiana H.

description: According to the placard, this park sits on a rock formed by some kind of prehistoric single-celled organism.  Awesome.  I saw this on google maps today and decided to get some fresh air and hike over.  It's a testament to my cardiovascular robustness that I didn't keel over and die at the top of this hill.  The best view of the city from inside the city (outside, that distinction would belong to the Marina Headlands).  Careful with your feets though -- there's broken 40 glass everywhere.
author: Phil K.

description: This place is the coolest!  For over a year, I've lived in the area and seen this hill protruding into the middle of my view.  So, one unseasonably warm day, I decided it was time to see what was the deal.  So, I started walking.....and walking......up.....and up.  195 steps up at Kirkham and 14th, to be exact.  Then, there was a mini-hike up the hill and I was rewarded with the most incredible view--the Pacific to the East Bay and directly downtown.  Absolutely beautiful and a bit of exercise all in the mix.
author: Jessica L.

description: After reading the reviews and seeing some of the beautiful pictures here, I had to see it myself. Yea, you're right. It's beautiful, a closer view comparing at the Twin Peaks. However, it is very scary walking around the edge. Definitely not a good place for kids. Today was hot, so it wasn't so windy up there.
author: The Black Cat C.

description: Beautiful.  This is a park, not a hike (FYI for people who think that this might be a trail).  Climb a flight of stairs and you see one of the most magnificent views of the city.  A little windy so bring a jacket.  Dog owners, please don't bring your pups here.  There's so much broken glass mixed into the sand  (found AFTER you finish climbing up the steps).  If you have a little pup, I guess you can carry him to the bench.
author: Shana Y.

description: Grand View, such a good place to sit and contemplate life. Bring warm clothes and a hat but really cool view and a good place to ponder things for a hour or so. It is a giant sand dune to remind you, since most of the sunset and Richmond districts are, so be prepared for sand in the shoes. Loss of star to the not very good upkeep.
author: Ryan O.

description: Absolutely lovely.  Easy to get parking, has a clear view of Golden Gate Park and the Pacific, something you won't find on Twin Peaks.  You'd think that there'd be a ton of reviews on a site with a view this amazing, but there aren't.  And really, that's the beauty of it--sitting on this hill is truly an escape.
author: Tony L.

description:
very sweet view; best i've seen of sf, from the west side at least.

check out this panorama i took: http://bit.ly/grandview
author: Ivan C.

description: Grand view doesn't begin to describe it. So glad my wandering took me here today. Such an amazing 360 view! As a newcomer to the city it was really cool to be up there by myself and feel like I discovered this cool place and just sit and contemplate the city and my place in it. Okay getting really sappy. It's beautiful; well worth a bus ride (if you dont live in the area) and the climb up the stairs.
author: Megan G.

description:
Living in the Outer Sunset, I have driven through the avenues thousands of times and never had a clue such an amazing park was right around the corner.  I think this park trumps Twin Peaks in terms of the amazing view.  You can literally see the entire Sunset down to Daly City, the beach and Pacific Ocean, all the way up the coast to Marin, GG Park, the tip of GG Bridge peeking over, all of the Haight Ashbury, downtown and the financial district, and all the way across the bay to Oakland.  You have to see it to believe it.  The only thing you can't see is the Mission and bayview as that is blocked by Twin Peaks.

Some interesting notes: the park is mostly sand, cool reminder of what the entire Sunset is built on.  There are trees up on the hill but they were all imported; none grow there naturally.  As mentioned before, there are some endangered species that grow right outside the footpath, so please be careful not to step on them.  There are some cool plants that you'll find attached to trees, they have yellow spores underneath the leaves and only need air and sunshine to grow.  This park rules.
author: Mr. A.

description: It's a little hike, but the view is very rewarding. Be there for a sunset. Watch out for the broken glass.
author: Josh B.

description: Surely this park has been raved about for its gorgeous views of the entire western section of the city and the Pacific, but I want to be sure it receives proper credit for its kick-ass workout providing abilities.  When jogging through the sunset or nearby GG park, Grand View is a short detour that will leave you short of breath.  The dozens upon dozens of vertical steps leading to the top end with the spectacular view which is a great excuse to catch your breath.  Stairs lead to the top on both the east and west side, which means there is plenty of potential for a serious stair loop / workout.
author: Morgen N.

description: Grand View Park is chill.  I love coming here when I'm heading to the city just to relax and enjoy the scenic view.  It is comparable to Twin Peaks, but I like this place better b/c of the beautiful and unique stairs.  The effort you put into walking up the stairs makes the experience up there worthwhile.  Bring a camera and a heavy jacket b/c it can get pretty windy up there.
author: Natalie P.

description: This place probably the most spectacular view of the sea. You can sort of see the curvature of the earth when you look westward. So cool that there's 2 kinds of flowers found only on that mound. The wallflowers looks beautiful. Definitely doing a picnic there on that one super awesome bench that sits on top of the hill.
author: Arnab B.

description: Worth the burn in your quads.  This is like Twin Peaks West.  The view of the west side of town and the ocean is uparalleled.  I recommend approaching from the East, up the stairs at the end of Moraga (start at 13th) for maximum pain. It's really really windy, but on a clear day this place can't be beat.
author: Eric S.

description: Crack a bottle here and enjoy the views, the best if you are near Golden Gate park or Inner Sunset district.
author: Chris S.

description:
With an amazing view like this, its no wonder that Grand View Park has been awarded the exclusive, dare I saw, ellusive, honor of being part of Tim V's "A-game". 

Recipe for success? Yeah, I got it. It goes a bit like this:

1.) Find hottie date (check)
2.) Get said hottie date to agree to an actual real date (no, that drunk pizza orgasmica run after getting tossed out of bar none does NOT count)....count that as a check too
3.) Wine, dine, bide your time  with date (usually 3 drinks worth etc. etc. bla bla blah)
4.) drop the a-game bomb on her/him- "yeah, there's this little hill I know with a view that puts seeing the sun set over El Pollo Loco on El Camino in redwood city to shame" 
5.) she/he will have no choice but to agree, you suave playah you
6.) stop into a classy liquor store to get that equally nice, classy,  bottle of boone's farm (on ice playah, its what Fiddy would do)
7.) chillax with your honey and watch the sun go down on the sunset, watch the lights of the boondocks that is my neighborhood wink on, and let the romance just flow...preferably, at a speed faster than the boone's farm running through your hot and bothered bodies
8.) don't know- still have yet to get to this step (see previous steps)

A-game baby, settle for nuthin' less
author: Tim V.

description: I've run around this place since I was a kid hahaha The view of the sunset and richmond districts is spectacular up there! Sitting up there at dawn and watching the sun come up is breath taking, just like when the sun is setting too! At times its sunny up there and then you see a blanket of fog rolling in too. It's quite nice =]
author: Jason C. J.

description: Even on the foggiest and coldest of days, this place is worth the little hike.  I'm sure on a clear day the views of Ocean Beach, GG Park, and Downtown are spectacular, but with the fog rolling in, it feels like you're floating above the city on a cloud.  Be forewarned however, this isn't your typical benches everywhere, spread a blanket over green grass and picnic type of park.  There are only a couple of actual benches, and some branches that have fallen strategically.  And the terrain is more ruffage than grass.  Great if you feel like going for a stroll/mini-hike...a wonderful view will be your reward.
author: Sarah L.

description:
i went here with my boyfriend.. 

we went here after looking at the beautiful mural staircase.. after losing calories and breaking a sweat from climbing those stairs (and then even more stair to get to the stop) that's when we saw the pretty view.. 

hard work pays off.
author: Reina A.

description: Because i live on the East side of Twin Peaks, being on this hill makes me feel like I'm not in San Francisco. It feels like another, much quieter city.
author: Geronimo G.

description:
one of the top view points in san francisco aside from twin peaks. imagine, from daly city all up the west coast and around to downtown within your imediate eyeline. freaking incredible! the hike up the hill is killer if your out of shape, but most definitely worth it! take a friend, a visitor, a boyfriend, a girlfriend, or just yourself!

also a side note, my friends and i always called this place Dr. Seuss Hill because of the funny shaped trees on top!
author: Jaei P.

description:
it is a GRAND VIEW up at grand view park. does not take long to travel to the top... so once you're at the top, sit down on a bench and enjoy the view. the view of ocean beach is glittering, if you're visiting on a sunny day sometime in the afternoon. 

to travel up to grand view... take the 6 to moraga and walk west, or take the 28 to moraga and walk east. towards the east is a elaborate mosaic staircase that will lead you up to grand view. take a close look at the lettering of the tiles on the mosaic stairs and see the messages. look at the staircase holistically and a "stairway to heaven" can been seen. then continue on the stairway to heaven to reach grand view. grand views are at the top of the hill.
author: Court L.

description: from the mosaic steps on the west side, to the shady green peak, this place is worth checking out if you're in the neighborhood.  a surprisingly far reaching view makes the very short hike worth while.
author: L J.

description: This park is gorgeous! Huge views, almost 360 views of the ocean, city, etc. It's off the beaten path, never too many people there, and never any tourists! Beautiful park to spend some time, soak in nature, and relax.
author: Amy B.

description: Definitely a site to see. It's well worth the walk and the view is absolutely breathe taking. You MUST access it through the Morage Tile Stairs to complete the experience! The site, again is amazing. Come on a clear sunny day and get a glimpse of the entire San Francisco. Spots your favorite spots and view the ocean, even a love bench to sit for hours.
author: Serena J.

description: Finally took my parents with me to this wonder spot about twenty minutes before sunset last night.  It is a definite hike up the stairs, but worth it.  The view itself is obviously easy to appreciate, but I was also drawn to the general atmosphere and mix of people who were also there to enjoy the view: a young couple, some families, and a nice looking group of friends in their 30's who plopped down with a case of Sierra Nevada's to enjoy the sunset.  Would definitely recommend coming here for a date.
author: J B.

description: we came here thinking that the giant cross of mount davidson was up here...but instead discovered something even more beautiful, the view! the mosaic stairs are really long.. but once you reach the top, ur in for a surprise. on a clear sunny day, we saw the entire city and could even make out golden gate bridge. pretty romantic for a date=)
author: christy w.

description: Beautiful. I've lived here 3 years and finally did this today! Best views of the city ever! I should have done this yesterday for the fireworks!
author: Sam H.

description: I lived within half a mile of this place for a year somehow without realizing that it even existed.  When you are climbing up the HUGE staircase to the top of the hill it gets progressively more and more windy and it totally took me off guard how ridiculously crazy the wind blows up there. Yes the wind really sucks, but the 360 degree view of the city totally makes up for it...you can see all of ocean beach on a clear day as well as the golden gate bridge and pretty much all the rest of San Francisco.  Usually there aren't too many tourists up top or anyone in general which makes it a great place to kind of relax and just take in the views while sitting on the single bench they have there.  If you live in the sunset and haven't been here, you really have to check it out....one of the few cool things you can do for free in SF that is actually worthwhile in my opinion.
author: Isaac W.

description: a fave of mine , its breathtaking daytime as it is night time , sunset is the most serene ,great photos of the city, so romantic.
author: Kayte S.

description: Grand View Park is just what the name implies, grand or should I Say a grand view for that matter.!  My friend, and I stumbled upon this place when we drove across the city one day, exploring different neighborhoods along the way.  Man,! what a hike up the hill; my feet were not killing yet, than god.!  Then, I could not believe the long flights of stairs that we had to climb.  I guess I had a a slight fear heights, being visually impaired and not being able to see everything as well.  But, we made up, a little tired and taken away by the breathtaking views of the City and the entire bay area.  I thought that it was a small greenbelt, but my friend pointed out that it was long and narrow and we ended up walking out a ways.  It was breathtaking listening to the sites and sounds of the city down below.  It is a very tranquil setting to go to to lose yourself  for a while and take a break from the hustle and bustle of the city.  We were up there for a while and the multiple flights of stairs did not mean a thing anymore.  We made it down safely and were both a little tired, especially after having to walk back down to the bottom of the hill.  It was well worth the effort.  We will definitely have to come back here for a picnic and a sunset.  This, like all San Francisco parks, will be around for years to come.  Keep up the good work City of San Francisco.!
author: Brian S.
